Title: None
Content:
Domestic, Regional, and International Reactions to the Syrian Revolution

Domestic, Regional, and International Reactions to the Syrian Revolution

Mohamad Fawaz  Mehmet Emin Cengiz        17 December 2024

Position Paper / Syria, Iraq, Israel / Regional Politics

Introduction:

The Syrian regime’s 61-year-old tyranny has finally fallen. The country’s new rulers have been trying to pave the way for a political transitional process. Regional countries also do not stay idle in this new period. Some regional countries have already started engaging in political talks with HTS and its allies through the Department of Political Affairs of the new government in the country. So far, meetings have been held with ambassadors of Iraq, Bahrain, Oman, Egypt, UAE, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and Italy. It was also announced that Qatar would soon open its embassy in Damascus.

It is safe to say that following the December 8th Revolution, Iran (and its proxies) emerged as the biggest losers along with the deposed Assad regime after the sweeping offensive led by HTS and Türkiye-backed Syrian rebels started on November 27th and ended on December 8th. Russia’s influence in the country has also shrunk. Nonetheless, it is still in a better position than Iran.

In an environment where developments are unfolding rapidly, it is essential to enumerate and understand the stances of Syrian, regional, and global actors to forecast what may come next.

Syrian Actors:

After the revolution, Syria is de facto divided into two main axes: Opposition forces (the new administration in Damascus) and the Syrian Democratic Forces. The new government controls approximately 70 percent of the country, while SDF controls around 30 percent. The SDF was expelled from Western Euphrates (Tel Rıf’at and Manbij) through the Türkiye-backed Syrian National Army’s ‘Operation Freedom Dawn’. In addition, the SDF withdrew from the Western Bank of Deir ez-Zour after the local Arab population revolted against it. In the upcoming period, the Arab-populated Eastern Syria will likely face new revolts, leading to the shrinking of the SDF control zones. New clashes between the SNA forces and SDF seem to be underway. A wing from the SDF’s Deir Ez-Zour Military Council also defected from it and joined the HTS-allied coalition. That said, SDF is trying to reach out to Damascus and cut a deal with HTS. By deciding to raise the flag of revolution, the SDF is trying to reconcile with HTS in the post-Assad regime era.

On the other side, the HTS-backed Syrian Salvation Government’s Prime Minister Mohammad Bashir has been appointed as the transitional period Prime Minister in the country, with a mandate that will expire on March 1, 2025. The transitional Prime Minister has already met with the HTS-backed Salvation Government’s and the ousted regime’s ministers in a meeting.

Although the situation on the ground seems to be on track among the new rulers of Syria, it is beyond doubt that they will vie for power in the upcoming period. Thus, a challenging period is ahead. And the new government has no option but to share power among different actors.

Regional Actors:

Türkiye

Türkiye emerged as the primary winner in the recent developments. The triumph of the new rulers of Syria is likely to incentivize a big chunk of the Syrian refugees in Türkiye to return to their homeland. Moreover, Türkiye also found the chance to clear SDF from the Western Euphrates, and it is now doubling down to do the same in the Eastern Euphrates in an effort to guarantee the safety of its southern borders due to the threats it has been perceiving from the SDF. Türkiye will also likely increase its trade activities with Syria as the dust settles slowly in the upcoming period.

Diplomatically, Türkiye was also the first country to send its officials to Damascus. The Turkish Intelligence Chief Ibrahim Kalın visited Damascus and held meetings with the new faces of the government in Damascus. Additionally, Türkiye has appointed Burhan Köroğlu as the charge d’affaires to Damascus, and opened its embassy after 12 years of hiatus.

Iran

Iran is undoubtedly the biggest loser in recent events. Iranian influence and investments through the sectarian militias and billions of dollars that Tehran has invested in Syria have evaporated during the lightning offensive. As a result, Tehran abandoned Bashar al-Assad to its fate following the blows that it had to deal with in the aftermath of the repercussions of the 7th of October. The Iranian officials continue to frame the revolution in Syria as an American-Israeli plot. Moreover, they also interchangeably accuse the Syrian regime, Türkiye, and Russia.

Although Iran has softened the rhetoric towards the new rulers of Syria, it is implausible that the new government in Syria will have a positive relationship with Iran due to Tehran’s track record of destroying Syria by supporting al-Assad via IRGC and Shiite militias from many countries including Afghanistan and Pakistan. Nonetheless, Iranian officials still claim that they got guarantees from the new administration in Damascus regarding the security of their embassy. Thus, they are willing to reopen it soon.

Iraq

In recent years, amid a series of political and regional shifts, Iraq has adopted a more introspective approach, leaning toward disengagement from external conflicts.

Iraqi officials have increasingly focused on preventing the spillover effects of the Syrian conflict from impacting their own country. As part of this strategy, Iraq has closed its borders with Syria to limit potential security threats, particularly following the arrival of around 4,000 Syrian soldiers who fled their military service. Various Iraqi factions remain on edge as they await new political leadership in Syria while maintaining a cautious stance by avoiding direct involvement in regional power struggles.

This cautious approach reflects the socio-economic internal fatigue and broader regional trends, such as Iran’s setbacks, which affected its proxies in the region in their regional role as well as their domestic power.

Lebanon

On the official front, Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati has called for Lebanon to distance itself from the Syrian conflict and to secure its borders at a time when the country has yet to recover from its war with Israel, and the ceasefire agreement remains fragile. After ensuring stability in the south, the Lebanese hope that the upcoming presidential election, scheduled for January 9th, will pave the way for recovery and the restoration of institutional order, beginning with the election of a president.

However, the fall of the Syrian regime is expected to embolden the Lebanese opposition forces against Hezbollah and its allies, reflecting a regional weakening of the organization. In response, Hezbollah is likely to cling more firmly to its socio-political role in Lebanon, seeing it as its last chance. This dynamic suggests that Lebanon is poised for a period of political tension and power struggles before reaching stability as the political landscape is reshaped to reflect the shifting balance of regional power. On the other hand, focus is expected to increase on the return of Syrian refugees, who number more than two million, as the reasons for their displacement have diminished.

Jordan

Jordan initially supported the Assad regime during the Syrian rebels’ offensive. Later, it changed the rhetoric and welcomed the change in the country. Also, the Jordanian ambassador in Damascus met with the new rulers of Syria.

Many Arab countries fear the return of the specter of the uprisings or a second rise of the Islamists that could threaten their rule, similar to the initial rise following the Arab Spring revolts.

For Jordan, in addition to these fears, its primary focus regarding Syria over the past years has been controlling borders and halting smuggling operations, a goal it has pursued through engagement with the Assad regime without achieving the desired outcomes. After the Assad regime’s downfall, Jordan, through its officials, expressed its readiness “to provide any assistance needed by the brotherly Syrian people.” Jordan fears that Syria might “slide into chaos,” a scenario that poses a major concern for maintaining security and stability within Jordan itself. In addition, Jordan has not hidden its concerns, as expressed by its officials, about the Israeli advances in Syria, which naturally represent a threat to Jordan’s security. Therefore, it is expected to see more significant Jordanian engagement with Syria’s new rulers, especially regarding border issues.

Egypt

Egypt’s response to the fall of the Syrian regime was cautious and delayed. When it came, the Egyptian Foreign Minister described the situation as a “change” and affirmed Egypt’s willingness to assist in easing the suffering of the Syrian people, supporting safe refugee returns, and participating in reconstruction efforts.

As a leading opponent of political Islam, Egypt remains deeply concerned about the transformation in Syria, fearing a second Arab spring wave, especially with Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham, an Islamist group, at the forefront of the change in Syria. Also, the Egyptian leaders fear the potential spread of jihadist movements, which could threaten its governance or compromise national security.

Despite economic challenges, Egypt has faced relatively fewer issues with its Syrian refugee population than other nations. However, it sees an opportunity to strengthen its economy and reclaim some of the regional influence it has lost in recent years by supporting refugee returns and participating in reconstruction efforts. Amidst these fears, the Egyptian ambassador met with the new administration officials in Syria.

Israel

Israel has maintained a military-centric approach to its view of the region. While the fall of Assad’s regime worked in Israel’s favor by disrupting the Iran-Hezbollah supply corridor and curbing Iranian influenc[TOO LONG, END]

Content:
A 3-day SMO Done Right - 2024 Syrian Rebel Offensive and the Resulting Collapse of the Regime Military in Northern Syria - Oryx

Home
Contact


Saturday, 7 December 2024
 
A 3-day SMO Done Right - 2024 Syrian Rebel Offensive and the Resulting Collapse of the Regime Military in Northern Syria
Jakub Janovsky Saturday, December 07, 2024 0 Comments

By Elmustek in collaboration with Jakub Janovsky and Buschlaid
The Syrian rebel offensive which commenced late on the 27th of November 2024 on positions of the Syrian Arab Army (SyAA) and affiliated forces collapsed regime positions throughout Idlib and Aleppo governorates, leading to the rout of government forces in both regions and allowing rebel forces to capture large amout of territory containing the city of Aleppo, multiple towns, and countless villages. 
While we for now dont know how far will rebels be able to advance, they are already at the gates of Hama city as of the time this article is being written. This massive rebel advance has resulted in incredible regime material losses - with almost all equipment being captured, not destroyed - making its losses extra painful for the regime and its allies (Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah) because now all those captured weapons and munitions can be used against their former owners.
This is only the latest case of the Syrian Arab Army (SAA) being the biggest supplier of weapons and ammo to the forces it has been fighting. But the amount of equipment and munitions captured from the regime forces during this rout from Aleppo and Idlib governorates has been unprecedented. And it isnt just quantity of weapons - rebel captures include a whole collection of powerful and complex weapons like fighter jets (even if only some of the captured ones are likely operational), long range MRLS, and SAM systems. While using these weapons systems will be difficult for rebels, if they mamage to make operational even just some of them, it would pose a serious problem for the regime military and its allies.
A detailed list of the destroyed and captured heavy weapons can be seen below.  
This list only includes captured vehicles and equipment of which photo or videographic evidence is available. Therefore, the amount of equipment destroyed or captured by Syrian rebel forces is undoubtedly higher than recorded here. Losses of trucks, jeeps, etc. might be added later. Small arms and munitions are not included in this list to preserve the sanity of people documenting regime losses.  
This list will be updated as additional footage becomes available.
Note: this list will at least for now list only equipment losses that happened on or before the regime collapse in Hama on December 5th 2024 - depending on the later events, this list might later be expanded, but if the regime falls, there would be no point in listing literally everything that the regimes military osed to own.

URL: https://www.irishtimes.com/world/middle-east/2024/12/07/syrian-rebels-claim-to-have-reached-damascus-suburbs-in-final-stage-of-offensive/
Title: None
Content:
Syrian rebels claim to have reached Damascus suburbs in ‘final stage’ of offensive

State news agency denies rumours that Bashar al-Assad has left country as his 24-year rule comes under major pressure

Syrian rebels have reached the suburbs of Damascus as part of a rapidly moving offensive that has seen them take over some of the country’s largest cities, according to opposition activists and a rebel commander.

It would be the first time that opposition forces have reached the outskirts of the capital since 2018, when Syrian troops recaptured the region adjacent to Damascus following a years-long siege.

Rami Abdurrahman, who heads the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, an opposition war monitor, said insurgents were active in the Damascus suburbs of Maadamiyah, Jaramana and Daraya on Saturday.

A commander with the insurgents, Hassan Abdul-Ghani, posted on the Telegram messaging app that opposition forces have started carrying out the “final stage” of their offensive by encircling Damascus. He added that insurgents were headed from southern Syria toward the city.

Lone suspect charged with murdering two Israeli embassy staff in shooting near Jewish museum in Washington

More than 350 lawyers and academics say Government not complying with international law obligations over Palestine crisis

Aid trucks enter Gaza after delays as pressure mounts on Israel

Netanyahu’s promise of Israel’s ‘total victory’ over Hamas is likely to remain elusive dream

The rebels, led by the Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) militant group, earlier said they had reached the edge of the central city of Homs as government forces attempted to buttress collapsing front lines and preserve Bashar al-Assad’s 24-year rule. Syria’s state news agency denied rumours that Assad has left the country, saying he is at work in Damascus.

The leader of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, a former al Qaeda affiliate, said in a video message on Saturday that the rebels were “in the final moments of liberating” Homs.

Since the rebels’ sweep into Aleppo a week ago, government defences have crumbled across the country at dizzying speed as insurgents rose up in places where the rebellion had long seemed over. Besides capturing Aleppo in the north, Hama in the centre and Deir al-Zor in the east, rebels took contol of Suweida and Deraa.

Syria’s military said it was carrying out air strikes around Hama and Homs and reinforcing on that front. It also said it was repositioning around Deraa and Suweida, without acknowledging their capture by rebels.

Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov said on Saturday it was inadmissible to allow what he called a terrorist group to take control of Syrian lands. He was speaking in Doha, Qatar after meeting the Turkish and Iranian foreign ministers.

Russia, a long-term ally of Syria, intervened in 2015 to prop up Damascus during Syria’s civil war, which began in 2011. It maintains a military presence in Syria, including a naval base and airbases in the cities of Tartus and Latakia, in the coastal region that is a stronghold of Assad’s Alawite sect.

Mr Lavrov said Russia would “help the Syrian army to counter the attacks of terrorists”.

The UN’s special envoy for Syria, Geir Pedersen, called for urgent talks to ensure an “orderly political transition”.

Speaking to reporters at the annual Doha Forum, he said the talks in Geneva, Switzerland would discuss the implementation of a UN resolution that called for a Syrian-led political process. Resolution 2254, adopted in 2015, called for the establishment of a transitional governing body, followed by the drafting of a new constitution and ending with UN-supervised elections.

The pace of events in Syria has stunned Arab capitals, western officials say, raising their fears of a fresh wave of regional instability.

Syria's civil war, which erupted in 2011 as an uprising against Assad's rule, dragged in big outside powers, created space for jihadist militants to plot attacks around the world and sent millions of refugees into neighbouring states.

Assad had long relied on allies to subdue the rebels, with Russian warplanes bombing from the skies while Iran sent allied forces including Lebanon’s Hizbullah and Iraqi militia to bolster the Syrian military and storm insurgent strongholds.

But Russia has been focused on the war in Ukraine since 2022 and Hizbullah’s leadership has been decimated this year in its own gruelling war with Israel.

Hizbullah sent some “supervising forces” to Homs on Friday but any significant deployment would risk exposure to Israeli air strikes, western officials said. Israel attacked two Lebanon-Syria border crossings on Friday, Lebanon said.

Iran-backed Iraqi militias are on high alert, with thousands of heavily armed fighters ready to deploy

CONTENT: The loss of Aleppo is a major reversal for Damascus and its allies and will return the issue of Syria to the top of the agenda in Russia-Türkiye relations. However, with Assad's regime now overthrown, Russia faces a strategic setback. Its previous interventions helped consolidate Assad's power since 2015. Russia now emphasizes political approaches to stabilize the region and safeguard its interests <citation>https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/coming-fight-syria</citation>.</note>\", \"<note>Russia’s ability to influence the situation in Syria has been complicated by its military commitments elsewhere, notably in Ukraine. As the rebels gained ground, Russia’s military presence and its plans to assist Assad were constrained, leading to a diplomatic focus <citation>https://www.moscowtimes.com/2024/12/08/how-russia-is-reacting-to-the-downfall-of-syrias-assad-a87260</citation>.</note>\", \"<note>In the aftermath of Assad's fall, Russia expressed readiness to assist Syrians through political support. Russia transitioned from military support to a diplomatic role, balancing its influence in the region amidst changes and protecting its geopolitical interests <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/moscow-is-still-ready-help-syrians-civil-war-is-their-burden-alone-says-lawmaker-2024-12-08/</citation>.</note>\"]}"
  }</arguments>
</tool_use>

<answer>
### Iran

Iran has played a pivotal role in the 2024 Syrian conflict, continuing its long-standing alliance with Syria. Consequently, the country's involvement is multifaceted and deeply entwined with its regional strategies:

- **Military Support**: Iran, alongside Russia, has provided critical military support to the Assad regime. This support has included airstrikes and troop deployments which have been instrumental in key battles, such as the capture of Aleppo in November 2024. This involvement underscores Iran's commitment to sustaining the Assad regime and countering opposition offensives <citation>https://www.armyrecognition.com/focus-analysis-conflicts/army/conflicts-in-the-world/syria-conflict-news/iran-and-russia-to-support-syrian-regime-with-airstrikes-and-troop-deployments</citation>.

- **Strategic Alliance**: Iran's alliance with Syria is rooted in a broader strategy to maintain the "Axis of Resistance," which aligns with Tehran's geopolitical interests in West Asia. This alliance is deemed vital for Iran to project its influence and counteract the influence of rival nations in the region <citation>https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/506992/Iran-s-strategic-resolve-defending-Syria-and-Axis-of-Resistance</citation>.

- **Proxy Warfare**: Iran employs proxy warfare tactics, notably through groups like Hezbollah, to fortify its position within Syria. This strategy not only supports the Assad regime but also enhances Iran's regional foothold <citation>https://blogs.timesofisrael.com/irans-terrorism-a-threat-to-syrias-stability/</citation>.

Iran's involvement is dual-faceted, involving direct military actions and strategic support through proxies, all aimed at sustaining the Assad regime and extending its influence across the region. These activities remain a cornerstone of Iran's foreign policy objectives amid the complex dynamics of the Syrian conflict.
</answer>

action_taken:
Based on the search results, here's a structured markdown section concerning Turkey's involvement in the 2024 Syrian conflict:

### Turkey

Turkey's role in the Syrian conflict has been marked by strategic maneuvering to extend its influence in the region. The ouster of Bashar al-Assad in December 2024 has opened new avenues for Turkey, which has historically supported Syrian opposition forces since the civil war began in 2011. Turkish-backed elements now control significant areas in northern Syria, having moved swiftly in the wake of Assad's fall to capture regions like Manbij from Kurdish militias <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/amid-syrias-upheaval-how-will-turkey-benefit/a-71017654</citation>.

Ankara's objectives include reversing the flow of Syrian refugees back into the northern territories it influences, leveraging peace along its borders to stabilize the region and manage domestic sentiment where refugee hosting is seen as economically burdensome <citation>https://www.newarab.com/analysis/how-turkey-aims-capitalise-syrias-rebel-offensive</citation>. Despite denying direct involvement in current offensives, Turkey has maintained support for the Syrian National Army, which plays a vital role in ongoing conflicts against Kurdish forces, aligning with its broader strategy to mitigate Kurdish influence near its frontier <citation>https://globalvoices.org/2024/12/24/the-complex-nature-of-turkeys-relations-with-syria/</citation>.

Turkey's policy shifts are also shaped by its interactions with global influencers, including the United States and Russia. Having previously lost initiative to these powers, Ankara has adjusted its policies, balancing between safeguarding its military presence and engaging in diplomatic negotiations <citation>https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/reconsidering-turkeys-influence-syrian-conflict</citation>. With the regime's collapse catching many off guard, Turkey's role in Syria is now more pivotal, as it navigates opportunities and challenges presented by the reshaping geopolitical landscape <citation>https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/mepo.12807</citation>.

This section outlines how Turkey's influence and military strategies are evolving in response to Assad's downfall, emphasizing both regional power dynamics and domestic implications.

URL: https://research.sharqforum.org/2024/12/17/domestic-regional-and-international-reactions-to-the-syrian-revolution/
Title: None
Content:
Domestic, Regional, and International Reactions to the Syrian Revolution

Domestic, Regional, and International Reactions to the Syrian Revolution

Mohamad Fawaz  Mehmet Emin Cengiz        17 December 2024

Position Paper / Syria, Iraq, Israel / Regional Politics

Introduction:

The Syrian regime’s 61-year-old tyranny has finally fallen. The country’s new rulers have been trying to pave the way for a political transitional process. Regional countries also do not stay idle in this new period. Some regional countries have already started engaging in political talks with HTS and its allies through the Department of Political Affairs of the new government in the country. So far, meetings have been held with ambassadors of Iraq, Bahrain, Oman, Egypt, UAE, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and Italy. It was also announced that Qatar would soon open its embassy in Damascus.

It is safe to say that following the December 8th Revolution, Iran (and its proxies) emerged as the biggest losers along with the deposed Assad regime after the sweeping offensive led by HTS and Türkiye-backed Syrian rebels started on November 27th and ended on December 8th. Russia’s influence in the country has also shrunk. Nonetheless, it is still in a better position than Iran.

In an environment where developments are unfolding rapidly, it is essential to enumerate and understand the stances of Syrian, regional, and global actors to forecast what may come next.

Syrian Actors:

After the revolution, Syria is de facto divided into two main axes: Opposition forces (the new administration in Damascus) and the Syrian Democratic Forces. The new government controls approximately 70 percent of the country, while SDF controls around 30 percent. The SDF was expelled from Western Euphrates (Tel Rıf’at and Manbij) through the Türkiye-backed Syrian National Army’s ‘Operation Freedom Dawn’. In addition, the SDF withdrew from the Western Bank of Deir ez-Zour after the local Arab population revolted against it. In the upcoming period, the Arab-populated Eastern Syria will likely face new revolts, leading to the shrinking of the SDF control zones. New clashes between the SNA forces and SDF seem to be underway. A wing from the SDF’s Deir Ez-Zour Military Council also defected from it and joined the HTS-allied coalition. That said, SDF is trying to reach out to Damascus and cut a deal with HTS. By deciding to raise the flag of revolution, the SDF is trying to reconcile with HTS in the post-Assad regime era.

On the other side, the HTS-backed Syrian Salvation Government’s Prime Minister Mohammad Bashir has been appointed as the transitional period Prime Minister in the country, with a mandate that will expire on March 1, 2025. The transitional Prime Minister has already met with the HTS-backed Salvation Government’s and the ousted regime’s ministers in a meeting.

Although the situation on the ground seems to be on track among the new rulers of Syria, it is beyond doubt that they will vie for power in the upcoming period. Thus, a challenging period is ahead. And the new government has no option but to share power among different actors.

Regional Actors:

Türkiye

Türkiye emerged as the primary winner in the recent developments. The triumph of the new rulers of Syria is likely to incentivize a big chunk of the Syrian refugees in Türkiye to return to their homeland. Moreover, Türkiye also found the chance to clear SDF from the Western Euphrates, and it is now doubling down to do the same in the Eastern Euphrates in an effort to guarantee the safety of its southern borders due to the threats it has been perceiving from the SDF. Türkiye will also likely increase its trade activities with Syria as the dust settles slowly in the upcoming period.

Diplomatically, Türkiye was also the first country to send its officials to Damascus. The Turkish Intelligence Chief Ibrahim Kalın visited Damascus and held meetings with the new faces of the government in Damascus. Additionally, Türkiye has appointed Burhan Köroğlu as the charge d’affaires to Damascus, and opened its embassy after 12 years of hiatus.

Iran

Iran is undoubtedly the biggest loser in recent events. Iranian influence and investments through the sectarian militias and billions of dollars that Tehran has invested in Syria have evaporated during the lightning offensive. As a result, Tehran abandoned Bashar al-Assad to its fate following the blows that it had to deal with in the aftermath of the repercussions of the 7th of October. The Iranian officials continue to frame the revolution in Syria as an American-Israeli plot. Moreover, they also interchangeably accuse the Syrian regime, Türkiye, and Russia.

Although Iran has softened the rhetoric towards the new rulers of Syria, it is implausible that the new government in Syria will have a positive relationship with Iran due to Tehran’s track record of destroying Syria by supporting al-Assad via IRGC and Shiite militias from many countries including Afghanistan and Pakistan. Nonetheless, Iranian officials still claim that they got guarantees from the new administration in Damascus regarding the security of their embassy. Thus, they are willing to reopen it soon.

Iraq

In recent years, amid a series of political and regional shifts, Iraq has adopted a more introspective approach, leaning toward disengagement from external conflicts.

Iraqi officials have increasingly focused on preventing the spillover effects of the Syrian conflict from impacting their own country. As part of this strategy, Iraq has closed its borders with Syria to limit potential security threats, particularly following the arrival of around 4,000 Syrian soldiers who fled their military service. Various Iraqi factions remain on edge as they await new political leadership in Syria while maintaining a cautious stance by avoiding direct involvement in regional power struggles.

This cautious approach reflects the socio-economic internal fatigue and broader regional trends, such as Iran’s setbacks, which affected its proxies in the region in their regional role as well as their domestic power.

Lebanon

On the official front, Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati has called for Lebanon to distance itself from the Syrian conflict and to secure its borders at a time when the country has yet to recover from its war with Israel, and the ceasefire agreement remains fragile. After ensuring stability in the south, the Lebanese hope that the upcoming presidential election, scheduled for January 9th, will pave the way for recovery and the restoration of institutional order, beginning with the election of a president.

However, the fall of the Syrian regime is expected to embolden the Lebanese opposition forces against Hezbollah and its allies, reflecting a regional weakening of the organization. In response, Hezbollah is likely to cling more firmly to its socio-political role in Lebanon, seeing it as its last chance. This dynamic suggests that Lebanon is poised for a period of political tension and power struggles before reaching stability as the political landscape is reshaped to reflect the shifting balance of regional power. On the other hand, focus is expected to increase on the return of Syrian refugees, who number more than two million, as the reasons for their displacement have diminished.

Jordan

Jordan initially supported the Assad regime during the Syrian rebels’ offensive. Later, it changed the rhetoric and welcomed the change in the country. Also, the Jordanian ambassador in Damascus met with the new rulers of Syria.

Many Arab countries fear the return of the specter of the uprisings or a second rise of the Islamists that could threaten their rule, similar to the initial rise following the Arab Spring revolts.

For Jordan, in addition to these fears, its primary focus regarding Syria over the past years has been controlling borders and halting smuggling operations, a goal it has pursued through engagement with the Assad regime without achieving the desired outcomes. After the Assad regime’s downfall, Jordan, through its officials, expressed its readiness “to provide any assistance needed by the brotherly Syrian people.” Jordan fears that Syria might “slide into chaos,” a scenario that poses a major concern for maintaining security and stability within Jordan itself. In addition, Jordan has not hidden its concerns, as expressed by its officials, about the Israeli advances in Syria, which naturally represent a threat to Jordan’s security. Therefore, it is expected to see more significant Jordanian engagement with Syria’s new rulers, especially regarding border issues.

Egypt

Egypt’s response to the fall of the Syrian regime was cautious and delayed. When it came, the Egyptian Foreign Minister described the situation as a “change” and affirmed Egypt’s willingness to assist in easing the suffering of the Syrian people, supporting safe refugee returns, and participating in reconstruction efforts.

As a leading opponent of political Islam, Egypt remains deeply concerned about the transformation in Syria, fearing a second Arab spring wave, especially with Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham, an Islamist group, at the forefront of the change in Syria. Also, the Egyptian leaders fear the potential spread of jihadist movements, which could threaten its governance or compromise national security.

Despite economic challenges, Egypt has faced relatively fewer issues with its Syrian refugee population than other nations. However, it sees an opportunity to strengthen its economy and reclaim some of the regional influence it has lost in recent years by supporting refugee returns and participating in reconstruction efforts. Amidst these fears, the Egyptian ambassador met with the new administration officials in Syria.

Israel

Israel has maintained a military-centric approach to its view of the region. While the fall of Assad’s regime worked in Israel’s favor by disrupting the Iran-Hezbollah supply corridor and curbing Iranian influenc[TOO LONG, END]
action_taken:
<answer>
### Domestic

Following the fall of the Assad regime in December 2024, the domestic landscape in Syria has been marked by significant shifts and challenges. The country is now primarily divided between the new administration in Damascus, backed by Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and Türkiye, and the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF). The new government controls approximately 70% of the country, while SDF controls about 30%. The ongoing power dynamics are complicated by the rebellious actions from Arab populations against SDF control, hinting at potential future conflicts.

The new rulers in Damascus, led by HTS, are focused on consolidating power through transitional governance. An HTS-backed Prime Minister, Mohammad Bashir, has been appointed for the transitional period set to end in March 2025. Despite having a functioning government, power struggles are anticipated as multiple factions negotiate their roles in the new Syria.

Domestically, the transition is seen as an opportunity to rebuild, but the path is fraught with challenges given the histories of conflict and division within the country. Engaging with various factions and ensuring stable governance will be critical for the nation's future as it attempts to move away from over six decades of autocratic rule under the Assad regime <citation>https://research.sharqforum.org/2024/12/17/domestic-regional-and-international-reactions-to-the-syrian-revolution/</citation>.
</answer>

The new rulers in Damascus, led by HTS, are focused on consolidating power through transitional governance. An HTS-backed Prime Minister, Mohammad Bashir, has been appointed for the transitional period set to end in March 2025. Despite having a functioning government, power struggles are anticipated as multiple factions negotiate their roles in the new Syria.

Domestically, the transition is seen as an opportunity to rebuild, but the path is fraught with challenges given the histories of conflict and division within the country. Engaging with various factions and ensuring stable governance will be critical for the nation's future as it attempts to move away from over six decades of autocratic rule under the Assad regime <citation>https://research.sharqforum.org/2024/12/17/domestic-regional-and-international-reactions-to-the-syrian-revolution/</citation>.
</answer>

action_taken:
<answer>
### Opening Advances

The opening advances of the 2024 Syrian conflict marked a dramatic shift in the ongoing civil strife. In late November and early December, opposition forces made substantial gains against government troops, capturing key regions and reigniting the conflict that had been in a stalemate for years.

1. **Strategic Seizures:**
   - Opposition forces, including the Syrian National Army (SNA), Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), and Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), rapidly advanced in northern Syria. Key strategic gains occurred in Aleppo and Hama, with the rebels capturing 20 villages <citation>https://tribune.com.pk/story/2514760/turmoil-in-syria-continues-after-assad-flees-countr</citation>.

2. **Key Players and Support:**
   - The SNA, backed by Turkey, played a significant role in northern Syria. Their success highlighted their capability to control key regions despite pressures from Assad-aligned forces and external actors like Russia <citation>https://genesysdefense.com/intl/advancements-and-strategic-shifts-syrian-rebel-operations-in-november-2024/</citation>.

3. **Incidents and Reactions:**
   - The opposition's capture of Aleppo on November 28, 2024, underscored the intense fighting in northwestern Syria. This further strained Assad's forces, which struggled to maintain control against the opposition's offensive <citation>https://www.newsweek.com/syrian-opposition-forces-advance-aleppo-amid-heavy-fighting-1993364</citation>.

These opening advances not only shifted territorial control but also pressured international stakeholders, including Turkey and Russia, to reassess their strategies and involvement in the region.
</answer>

action_taken:
<answer>
### Clashes between SDF and opposition forces

A series of violent clashes have erupted between the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) and various opposition forces. These incidents have unfolded in the context of a complex and escalating conflict involving multiple regional actors.

#### Key Events
- **Iranian-Backed Tribal Offensives**: Iranian-backed tribal forces have launched significant attacks on SDF positions. The Al Aqeedat tribe, under the leadership of Ibrahim Al-Hefl, has been a prominent actor in this offensive, reportedly receiving Iranian military support and training <citation>https://www.iranintl.com/en/202408080107</citation>.

- **Clashes with Turkish-Backed Factions**: The SDF has also engaged in fierce battles with Turkish-backed opposition factions, resulting in the deaths of numerous fighters. The city of Manbij has been a focal point of these confrontations <citation>https://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/241220241</citation>.

#### Analysis
These clashes underline the heightened tensions within northern Syria and pose challenges for international actors such as the United States, which supports the SDF. The involvement of Iranian-backed groups complicates the geopolitical landscape, particularly in light of Iran's strategic objectives in the region <citation>https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/08/clashes-between-arab-tribes-sdf-forces-syria-pose-challenge-us</citation>.

Despite these challenges, the SDF continues to face threats from Islamic State sleeper cells, former regime forces, and other opposition groups, which together create a volatile and multifaceted conflict environment <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/11/syria-which-groups-have-been-fighting-each-other-and-where/</citation>.
</answer>

Content:
A 3-day SMO Done Right - 2024 Syrian Rebel Offensive and the Resulting Collapse of the Regime Military in Northern Syria - Oryx

Home
Contact


Saturday, 7 December 2024
 
A 3-day SMO Done Right - 2024 Syrian Rebel Offensive and the Resulting Collapse of the Regime Military in Northern Syria
Jakub Janovsky Saturday, December 07, 2024 0 Comments

By Elmustek in collaboration with Jakub Janovsky and Buschlaid
The Syrian rebel offensive which commenced late on the 27th of November 2024 on positions of the Syrian Arab Army (SyAA) and affiliated forces collapsed regime positions throughout Idlib and Aleppo governorates, leading to the rout of government forces in both regions and allowing rebel forces to capture large amout of territory containing the city of Aleppo, multiple towns, and countless villages. 
While we for now dont know how far will rebels be able to advance, they are already at the gates of Hama city as of the time this article is being written. This massive rebel advance has resulted in incredible regime material losses - with almost all equipment being captured, not destroyed - making its losses extra painful for the regime and its allies (Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah) because now all those captured weapons and munitions can be used against their former owners.
This is only the latest case of the Syrian Arab Army (SAA) being the biggest supplier of weapons and ammo to the forces it has been fighting. But the amount of equipment and munitions captured from the regime forces during this rout from Aleppo and Idlib governorates has been unprecedented. And it isnt just quantity of weapons - rebel captures include a whole collection of powerful and complex weapons like fighter jets (even if only some of the captured ones are likely operational), long range MRLS, and SAM systems. While using these weapons systems will be difficult for rebels, if they mamage to make operational even just some of them, it would pose a serious problem for the regime military and its allies.
A detailed list of the destroyed and captured heavy weapons can be seen below.  
This list only includes captured vehicles and equipment of which photo or videographic evidence is available. Therefore, the amount of equipment destroyed or captured by Syrian rebel forces is undoubtedly higher than recorded here. Losses of trucks, jeeps, etc. might be added later. Small arms and munitions are not included in this list to preserve the sanity of people documenting regime losses.  
This list will be updated as additional footage becomes available.
Note: this list will at least for now list only equipment losses that happened on or before the regime collapse in Hama on December 5th 2024 - depending on the later events, this list might later be expanded, but if the regime falls, there would be no point in listing literally everything that the regimes military osed to own.
(Click on the numbers to get a picture of each individual captured or destroyed vehicle)

URL: https://www.irishtimes.com/world/middle-east/2024/12/07/syrian-rebels-claim-to-have-reached-damascus-suburbs-in-final-stage-of-offensive/
Title: None
Content:
Syrian rebels claim to have reached Damascus suburbs in ‘final stage’ of offensive

State news agency denies rumours that Bashar al-Assad has left country as his 24-year rule comes under major pressure

Syrian rebels have reached the suburbs of Damascus as part of a rapidly moving offensive that has seen them take over some of the country’s largest cities, according to opposition activists and a rebel commander.

It would be the first time that opposition forces have reached the outskirts of the capital since 2018, when Syrian troops recaptured the region adjacent to Damascus following a years-long siege.

Rami Abdurrahman, who heads the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, an opposition war monitor, said insurgents were active in the Damascus suburbs of Maadamiyah, Jaramana and Daraya on Saturday.

A commander with the insurgents, Hassan Abdul-Ghani, posted on the Telegram messaging app that opposition forces have started carrying out the “final stage” of their offensive by encircling Damascus. He added that insurgents were headed from southern Syria toward the city.

Lone suspect charged with murdering two Israeli embassy staff in shooting near Jewish museum in Washington

More than 350 lawyers and academics say Government not complying with international law obligations over Palestine crisis

Aid trucks enter Gaza after delays as pressure mounts on Israel

Netanyahu’s promise of Israel’s ‘total victory’ over Hamas is likely to remain elusive dream

The rebels, led by the Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) militant group, earlier said they had reached the edge of the central city of Homs as government forces attempted to buttress collapsing front lines and preserve Bashar al-Assad’s 24-year rule. Syria’s state news agency denied rumours that Assad has left the country, saying he is at work in Damascus.

The leader of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, a former al Qaeda affiliate, said in a video message on Saturday that the rebels were “in the final moments of liberating” Homs.

Since the rebels’ sweep into Aleppo a week ago, government defences have crumbled across the country at dizzying speed as insurgents rose up in places where the rebellion had long seemed over. Besides capturing Aleppo in the north, Hama in the centre and Deir al-Zor in the east, rebels took contol of Suweida and Deraa.

Syria’s military said it was carrying out air strikes around Hama and Homs and reinforcing on that front. It also said it was repositioning around Deraa and Suweida, without acknowledging their capture by rebels.

Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov said on Saturday it was inadmissible to allow what he called a terrorist group to take control of Syrian lands. He was speaking in Doha, Qatar after meeting the Turkish and Iranian foreign ministers.

Russia, a long-term ally of Syria, intervened in 2015 to prop up Damascus during Syria’s civil war, which began in 2011. It maintains a military presence in Syria, including a naval base and airbases in the cities of Tartus and Latakia, in the coastal region that is a stronghold of Assad’s Alawite sect.

Mr Lavrov said Russia would “help the Syrian army to counter the attacks of terrorists”.

The UN’s special envoy for Syria, Geir Pedersen, called for urgent talks to ensure an “orderly political transition”.

Speaking to reporters at the annual Doha Forum, he said the talks in Geneva, Switzerland would discuss the implementation of a UN resolution that called for a Syrian-led political process. Resolution 2254, adopted in 2015, called for the establishment of a transitional governing body, followed by the drafting of a new constitution and ending with UN-supervised elections.

The pace of events in Syria has stunned Arab capitals, western officials say, raising their fears of a fresh wave of regional instability.

Syria's civil war, which erupted in 2011 as an uprising against Assad's rule, dragged in big outside powers, created space for jihadist militants to plot attacks around the world and sent millions of refugees into neighbouring states.

Assad had long relied on allies to subdue the rebels, with Russian warplanes bombing from the skies while Iran sent allied forces including Lebanon’s Hizbullah and Iraqi militia to bolster the Syrian military and storm insurgent strongholds.

But Russia has been focused on the war in Ukraine since 2022 and Hizbullah’s leadership has been decimated this year in its own gruelling war with Israel.

Hizbullah sent some “supervising forces” to Homs on Friday but any significant deployment would risk exposure to Israeli air strikes, western officials said. Israel attacked two Lebanon-Syria border crossings on Friday, Lebanon said.

Iran-backed Iraqi militias are on high alert, with thousands of heavily armed fighters ready to deploy

Based on the search results, I will compile the requested markdown section focusing on Ukraine's involvement and perspective concerning the 2024 Syrian conflict. Here is the result:

### Ukraine

**Overview:**
Ukraine has positioned itself as an active observer and participant in the 2024 Syrian crisis, focusing on diplomatic support and strategic partnerships with the new Syrian government.

**Involvement and Actions:**
1. **Support for Syrian Rebels:**
   - Russia accused Ukraine of backing Syrian rebels, claiming Ukrainian intelligence was involved in supporting Islamist groups opposing the Assad regime <citation>https://www.kyivpost.com/post/43256</citation>.
   - Allegations persist that Ukraine has provided FPV drones to Syrian rebels in battle zones like Aleppo, aiding their offensives <citation>https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/has-ukraine-helped-syrian-rebel-offensive-aleppo</citation>.

2. **Military Engagement:**
   - Reports have emerged about Ukraine sending special forces to Syria to challenge Russian interests, aiming to exploit Russia's military overstretch <citation>https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-special-forces-syria-attack-russians-new-war-front-report-2024-6?op=1</citation>.

**Reaction to Assad's Fall:**
- Following Assad's overthrow, Ukraine's Foreign Ministry expressed a readiness to restore relations with Syria and emphasized the fall as indicative of Russia's inability to support allies effectively <citation>https://newsukraine.rbc.ua/news/ukraine-reacts-to-the-fall-of-assad-s-regime-1733665867.html</citation>.

**International Relations and Future Plans:**
- Ukraine has initiated diplomatic ties with Syria's new leadership, seeking to support the new government and forge strategic economic and political partnerships <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/30/syria-and-ukraine-seek-strategic-partnerships-as-senior-officials-meet</citation>.
- Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced efforts to establish mechanisms for delivering food aid to Syria, highlighting a commitment to humanitarian cooperation <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/ukraine-set-up-mechanism-supply-food-syria-zelenskiy-says-2024-12-14/</citation>.

This structured summary highlights Ukraine's multidimensional role in the Syrian conflict, blending military involvement, diplomatic strategies, and humanitarian efforts.

action_taken:
<answer>
Based on the search results, here's a structured markdown section concerning Turkey's involvement in the 2024 Syrian conflict:

### Turkey

Turkey's role in the Syrian conflict has been marked by strategic maneuvering to extend its influence in the region. The ouster of Bashar al-Assad in December 2024 has opened new avenues for Turkey, which has historically supported Syrian opposition forces since the civil war began in 2011. Turkish-backed elements now control significant areas in northern Syria, having moved swiftly in the wake of Assad's fall to capture regions like Manbij from Kurdish militias <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/amid-syrias-upheaval-how-will-turkey-benefit/a-71017654</citation>.

Ankara's objectives include reversing the flow of Syrian refugees back into the northern territories it influences, leveraging peace along its borders to stabilize the region and manage domestic sentiment where refugee hosting is seen as economically burdensome <citation>https://www.newarab.com/analysis/how-turkey-aims-capitalise-syrias-rebel-offensive</citation>. Despite denying direct involvement in current offensives, Turkey has maintained support for the Syrian National Army, which plays a vital role in ongoing conflicts against Kurdish forces, aligning with its broader strategy to mitigate Kurdish influence near its frontier <citation>https://globalvoices.org/2024/12/24/the-complex-nature-of-turkeys-relations-with-syria/</citation>.

Turkey's policy shifts are also shaped by its interactions with global influencers, including the United States and Russia. Having previously lost initiative to these powers, Ankara has adjusted its policies, balancing between safeguarding its military presence and engaging in diplomatic negotiations <citation>https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/reconsidering-turkeys-influence-syrian-conflict</citation>. With the regime's collapse catching many off guard, Turkey's role in Syria is now more pivotal, as it navigates opportunities and challenges presented by the reshaping geopolitical landscape <citation>https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/mepo.12807</citation>.

This section outlines how Turkey's influence and military strategies are evolving in response to Assad's downfall, emphasizing both regional power dynamics and domestic implications.
</answer>

### Russia

- **Military Involvement**: Russia has maintained military bases in Syria, including Tartus and Hmeimim, which have been crucial for projecting power and supporting the Assad regime. After Assad's regime was overthrown, Russia faced a strategic setback despite previous military successes in consolidating Assad's power since 2015. Russia is now focusing on political approaches to stabilize the region and protect its interests <citation>https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/coming-fight-syria</citation>.

- **Military Constraints**: Russia's military resources have been strained due to its involvement in Ukraine, complicating its ability to maintain the same level of influence in Syria. As rebels made gains, Russia's military presence was constrained, leading to a shift in focus towards diplomatic efforts <citation>https://www.moscowtimes.com/2024/12/08/how-russia-is-reacting-to-the-downfall-of-syrias-assad-a87260</citation>.

- **Diplomatic Strategy**: Following the fall of Assad, Russia expressed a readiness to assist Syrians through political means. This marks a strategic transition from military support to adopting a diplomatic role, aiming to safeguard its regional influence amidst the transition <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/moscow-is-still-ready-help-syrians-civil-war-is-their-burden-alone-says-lawmaker-2024-12-08/</citation>.

[7]:
TITLE: Syria Transition: Nothing Left to Lose and Everything to Gain
URL: https://www.dohainstitute.org/en/PoliticalStudies/Pages/the-t
action_taken:
<answer>
### Immediate Aftermath

The immediate aftermath of Assad's fall in December 2024 marked a significant shift in Syria's political landscape, as rebel forces, particularly those led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), took control. The sudden power vacuum led to both regional instability and uncertainty. A transitional government was declared, led by Ahmad al-Sharaa, but the nation's future remained precarious as ISIS and other extremist groups threatened to exploit the chaos <citation>https://rcsgs.org/publications/blog/the-fall-of-bashar-al-assad-and-its-implications</citation>.

Internationally, reactions varied. Russia and Iran, Assad's long-time allies, had already distanced themselves, leading to the regime's vulnerability <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-10161/</citation>. Meanwhile, countries like Austria paused asylum applications amid the upheaval, reflecting concerns over potential refugee surges <citation>https://www.habtoorresearch.com/programmes/fall-of-al-assad/</citation>. In contrast, western nations cautiously welcomed the prospect of a new government, hopeful for a more stable Syria but wary of the extremist elements within the coalition <citation>https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/syria-what-is-the-situation-five-months-after-assads-fall/</citation>.

Domestically, Syria faced massive humanitarian challenges. With millions displaced and much of the infrastructure destroyed, immediate international assistance was crucial. However, the classification of HTS as a terrorist organization by the UN complicated diplomatic engagements, further challenging the transitional government's efforts to stabilize the nation <citation>https://www.iiss.org/online-analysis/online-analysis/2025/03/regional-reactions-to-the-transition-in-syria/</citation>.

Neighboring countries like Jordan expressed readiness to support the Syrian population, both fearing instability and recognizing the potential need for humanitarian aid <citation>https://research.sharqforum.org/2024/12/17/domestic-regional-and-international-reactions-to-the-syrian-revolution/</citation>. In contrast, Israel moved swiftly to secure its interests, taking control of strategic areas previously disengaged by Syrian forces, underlining the geopolitical complexities in the aftermath of Assad’s fall <citation>https://aoav.org.uk/2024/the-foreign-forces-in-syrias-conflict-a-brief-explainer/</citation>.
</answer>

action_taken:
<answer>
### Russia

- **Military Involvement**: Russia has maintained military bases in Syria, including Tartus and Hmeimim, to project power and support the Assad regime. With Assad's regime overthrown, Russia faces a strategic setback despite earlier interventions that consolidated Assad's power. Currently, Russia emphasizes political approaches to stabilize the region and safeguard its interests <citation>https://www.rusi.org/explore-our-research/publications/commentary/coming-fight-syria</citation>.

- **Military Constraints**: Russian military resources are tied down due to commitments in Ukraine, limiting its influence in Syria. As rebels gained ground, Russia's military plans to assist Assad were restricted, leading to a diplomatic focus <citation>https://www.moscowtimes.com/2024/12/08/how-russia-is-reacting-to-the-downfall-of-syrias-assad-a87260</citation>.

- **Diplomatic Strategy**: After Assad's fall, Russia expressed readiness to assist Syrians through political support, transitioning from a military approach to a diplomatic role to protect its geopolitical interests <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/moscow-is-still-ready-help-syrians-civil-war-is-their-burden-alone-says-lawmaker-2024-12-08/</citation>.
</answer>

Here is the structured article section focusing on Ukraine's involvement and perspective concerning the 2024 Syrian conflict:

### Ukraine

**Overview:**
Ukraine has positioned itself as an active participant in the 2024 Syrian crisis, focusing on diplomatic support and strategic partnerships with the new Syrian government.

**Involvement and Actions:**
1. **Support for Syrian Rebels:**
   - Russia accused Ukraine of backing Syrian rebels, claiming Ukrainian intelligence was involved in supporting Islamist groups opposing the Assad regime <citation>https://www.kyivpost.com/post/43256</citation>.
   - Allegations persist that Ukraine provided FPV drones to Syrian rebels in battle zones like Aleppo, aiding their offensives <citation>https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/has-ukraine-helped-syrian-rebel-offensive-aleppo</citation>.

2. **Military Engagement:**
   - Reports have emerged about Ukraine sending special forces to Syria to challenge Russian interests, exploiting Russia's military overstretch <citation>https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-special-forces-syria-attack-russians-new-war-front-report-2024-6?op=1</citation>.

**Reaction to Assad's Fall:**
- Ukraine's Foreign Ministry expressed a readiness to restore relations with Syria and emphasized Assad's fall as indicative of Russia's inability to support allies effectively <citation>https://newsukraine.rbc.ua/news/ukraine-reacts-to-the-fall-of-assad-s-regime-1733665867.html</citation>.

**International Relations and Future Plans:**
- Ukraine has initiated diplomatic ties with Syria's new leadership, seeking to support the new government and forge strategic economic and political partnerships <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/30/syria-and-ukraine-seek-strategic-partnerships-as-senior-officials-meet</citation>.
- Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced efforts to establish mechanisms for delivering food aid to Syria, highlighting a commitment to humanitarian cooperation <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/ukraine-set-up-mechanism-supply-food-syria-zelenskiy-says-2024-12-14/</citation>.

This summary provides insights into Ukraine's multidimensional role in the Syrian conflict, blending military involvement, diplomatic strategies, and humanitarian efforts.

<answer>
## Offensive

The recent phase of the 2024 Syrian conflict has been marked by significant opposition offensives, notably "Operation Deter Aggression" and "Operation Dawn of Freedom." These operations have been pivotal, leading to the capture of at least 237 cities, towns, villages, and military bases from Syrian regime forces <citation>https://www.syriaweekly.com/p/special-syria-nov-26-dec-3-2024</citation>. 

The opposition forces have executed substantial offensives in regions like western Aleppo, resulting in the death of at least 89 individuals and the overtaking of a Syrian military base <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>. This offensive momentum has posed a strategic opportunity for Turkey while simultaneously challenging Russia, which has staunchly supported the Assad regime <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

The insurgents have notably reached the outskirts of Damascus, creating a scenario that threatens to drastically alter the power dynamics within the region <citation>https://www.npr.org/2024/12/07/g-s1-37295/syria-insurgents-have-reached-suburbs-damascus</citation>. This is part of a broader effort by Syrian opposition groups to change the status quo that has plagued the region under a semi-ceasefire agreement, challenging both local government forces and foreign actors like Russia and Iran to reassess their strategies in Syria <citation>https://gcclub.org/2024/12/02/syrias-rebel-offensive-why-now-and-what-could-happen-next/</citation>.

In summary, the offensive efforts by the opposition forces within the 2024 Syrian conflict are characterized by significant territorial gains and strategic threats to the Assad regime, which could lead to a realignment of regional powers and push international stakeholders to seek new resolutions in addressing the Syrian crisis.
</answer>
next_observation:
<answer>
## Offensive

The recent phase of the 2024 Syrian conflict has been marked by significant opposition offensives, notably "Operation Deter Aggression" and "Operation Dawn of Freedom." These operations have been pivotal, leading to the capture of at least 237 cities, towns, villages, and military bases from Syrian regime forces <citation>https://www.syriaweekly.com/p/special-syria-nov-26-dec-3-2024</citation>. 

The opposition forces have executed substantial offensives in regions like western Aleppo, resulting in the death of at least 89 individuals and the overtaking of a Syrian military base <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>. This offensive momentum has posed a strategic opportunity for Turkey while simultaneously challenging Russia, which has staunchly supported the Assad regime <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

The insurgents have notably reached the outskirts of Damascus, creating a scenario that threatens to drastically alter the power dynamics within the region <citation>https://www.npr.org/2024/12/07/g-s1-37295/syria-insurgents-have-reached-suburbs-damascus</citation>. This is part of a broader effort by Syrian opposition groups to change the status quo that has plagued the region under a semi-ceasefire agreement, challenging both local government forces and foreign actors like Russia and Iran to reassess their strategies in Syria <citation>https://gcclub.org/2024/12/02/syrias-rebel-offensive-why-now-and-what-could-happen-next/</citation>.

In summary, the offensive efforts by the opposition forces within the 2024 Syrian conflict are characterized by significant territorial gains and strategic threats to the Assad regime, which could lead to a realignment of regional powers and push international stakeholders to seek new resolutions in addressing the Syrian crisis.
</answer>

action_taken:
<answer>
### Russia

#### Background and Objectives
Russia has been a significant player in the Syrian conflict since its direct military involvement commenced in 2015. The main objectives for Russia include securing its military foothold in the Middle East and preserving its influence over Syrian affairs. By backing the Assad regime, Russia has sought to position itself as a counterbalance to Western powers in the region and to project itself as an indispensable global power broker <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/moscow-is-still-ready-help-syrians-civil-war-is-their-burden-alone-says-lawmaker-2024-12-08/</citation>.

#### Recent Developments
In 2024, the situation in Syria saw a resurgence of conflict, putting Russia on the back foot after years of relative stability. The rebel offensive in Aleppo and Idlib provinces, backed by pro-Turkish forces, marked a significant escalation that Russia was unprepared for. This has led to a re-evaluation of its military strategy in coordination with fellow Assad ally Iran and opposition supporter Turkey <citation>https://edition.cnn.com/2024/12/01/middleeast/syrian-regime-airstrikes-opposition-forces-intl/</citation>.

#### Military Response
As the Syrian civil war reignited, Russia faced challenges in maintaining its military commitments due to its simultaneous involvement in Ukraine. Russian forces conducted air raids on opposition territories to curb the advancement of Islamist-led rebels but have had to contend with the diversion of military resources to Ukraine <citation>https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2024/12/02/syria-russia-conduct-deadly-strikes-to-push-back-islamist-advance-a87187</citation>.

#### Challenges and Strategic Concerns
Russia's diplomatic engagements have emphasized the prevention of Syrian disintegration into chaos after the insurgent advances. Nevertheless, the fall of Aleppo to rebel forces marked a symbolic defeat for Russia, challenging its assertive influence over the region. The disruptions in Syria also strained Russia's relationships with Turkey and Iran, necessitating complex negotiations to recalibrate military and political dynamics <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/03/world/middleeast/syria-rebel-offensive-iran-russia.html</citation>.

#### International Reactions
The fall of Bashar al-Assad was a pivotal event that drew international focus. Russia, meanwhile, maintained its stance on the necessity of a political resolution to the conflict, urging factions to avoid violence. Despite these diplomatic overtures, on-the-ground realities pushed Russia to act militarily while engaging in high-stakes diplomacy to safeguard its strategic interests in Syria <citation>https://www.newsweek.com/how-russia-iran-china-israel-responded-assads-ouster-syria-1997352</citation>.
</answer>

Based on the search results, I will generate the content for the "Offensive" section of the article. This section will summarize key events and provide analysis of the opposition offensives during the 2024 Syrian conflict.

```markdown
### Offensive

- **Operation Deter Aggression and Operation Dawn of Freedom:** By December 3, 2024, these two major offensives by armed opposition groups resulted in the capture of at least 237 cities, towns, villages, and military bases from the Syrian regime <citation>https://www.syriaweekly.com/p/special-syria-nov-26-dec-3-2024</citation>.

- **Advancements in Aleppo:** A significant offensive in the western Aleppo district led to the deaths of at least 89 people and the capture of a Syrian military base. Rebel groups, including Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, advanced to within about six miles of Aleppo, posing a challenge to the pro-regime militias attempting to counter these gains <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>.

- **Strategic Impact on Regional Dynamics:** These successful offensives impacted regional dynamics, presenting opportunities for Turkey and challenges for Russia, as the balance of power shifted among these countries <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

- **Rebel Strategy and Consequences:** The offensives were not only military tactics but also strategic maneuvers to force regional actors like Turkey and Russia to accept new realities on the ground, challenging the notion of a semi-ceasefire from opposing forces <citation>https://gcclub.org/2024/12/02/syrias-rebel-offensive-why-now-and-what-could-happen-next/</citation>.

These events illustrate a critical period in the Syrian conflict, marking significant territorial gains for the opposition and altering the geopolitical landscape.
```

This content provides a structured and concise overview of the major opposition offensives during 2024, drawing from available search results and analyses.

Syria's President Bashar al-Assad is backed by Russia and Iran, both of which have confirmed they will help his army fight back after Aleppo, the country's second city, fell out of government control. For the first time since the civil war started more than a decade ago, the country's second city "is out of control of Syrian regime forces," Observatory director Rami Abdel Rahman said on Sunday. Russia, which first intervened directly in the Syrian war in 2015, said Monday it continued to support Assad.

Now that we have gathered relevant information on Russia's involvement in the 2024 Syrian conflict, I will create a structured section for the article focusing on that topic. Here's the markdown-formatted content:

```markdown
### Russia

#### Overview
Russia has played a significant role in the Syrian conflict, maintaining military and political influence in the region since its direct intervention in 2015. In 2024, following the fall of the Assad government, Russia's position in Syria appeared increasingly precarious.

#### Military Involvement
Russia continued to support Syrian government forces through joint military operations. Despite the loss of Aleppo to rebel forces, Russia, alongside Syria, conducted airstrikes against Islamist-led rebels who had seized control of significant areas. The resurgence of conflict marked the largest military escalation since the ceasefire brokered by Russia and Türkiye in 2020 [source](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2024/12/02/syria-russia-conduct-deadly-strikes-to-push-back-islamist-advance-a87187).

#### Political and Strategic Interests
Throughout the conflict, Russia aimed to maintain its military presence and geopolitical influence by securing its bases, which remain strategically important for its operations in the Mediterranean and broader Middle East. Despite the shifting alliances and changes in Syrian governance, Russia has sought to bolster its regional influence while engaging in negotiations with other key players, including Iran and Türkiye [source](https://theworld.org/stories/2024/12/09/russias-military-role-in-syria).

#### Challenges and Diplomacy
The fall of Assad and the rise of opposition groups presented new challenges for Russia. Negotiations with the new Syrian authorities were ongoing, and Russia emphasized its role in ensuring regional stability and security. The situation also influenced Russia's broader geopolitical strategies, as it navigates its interests in the Syrian theater alongside other international conflicts [source](https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2024/12/08/how-russia-is-reacting-to-the-downfall-of-syrias-assad-a87260).

#### Conclusion
Despite the setbacks, Russia remains a crucial actor in the Syrian conflict. Its continued engagement in military and diplomatic efforts underscores its commitment to sustaining influence in the Middle East, even amid a rapidly changing political landscape [source](https://carnegieendowment.org/russia-eurasia/politika/2024/12/russia-syria-uprising-problems?lang=en).
```

This content provides an overview, military involvement, political strategy, challenges, and conclusion of Russia's actions and role in the 2024 Syrian conflict, aligned with the latest available data on the subject.

To provide an outline for the "Offensive" section related to the 2024 Syrian conflict, I will utilize the information from the search results and create a structured response.

```markdown
### Offensive

- **Operation Deter Aggression and Operation Dawn of Freedom:** As of December 3, 2024, these combined offensives by opposition forces have captured numerous strategic locations, including 237 cities, towns, villages, and military bases. This marks a significant shift in control from the Syrian regime to opposition groups <citation>https://www.syriaweekly.com/p/special-syria-nov-26-dec-3-2024</citation>.

- **Advancements in Aleppo:** A major offensive in western Aleppo resulted in the deaths of at least 89 individuals and the capture of a military base. The rebels, including Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, advanced close to Aleppo, challenging regime forces <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>.

- **Impact on Regional Dynamics:** The offensives provided opportunities for Turkey and posed challenges for Russia, affecting the power balance among key players like Russia, Iran, and Turkey <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

- **Strategic Objectives:** Beyond military gains, the offensives aimed to change regional dynamics and challenge the semi-ceasefire conditions, compelling countries like Turkey and Russia to adapt to the newly established facts on the ground <citation>https://gcclub.org/2024/12/02/syrias-rebel-offensive-why-now-and-what-could-happen-next/</citation>.
```

This structured section captures the key points of the opposition offensives during the 2024 Syrian conflict, providing a clear overview of the situation and its implications.

action_taken:
I'll provide the structured markdown section for the "Offensive" within the context of the 2024 Syrian conflict, integrating the most relevant information from the search results.

```markdown
### Offensive

- **Operation Deter Aggression and Operation Dawn of Freedom:** By December 3, 2024, these significant offensives led by opposition groups resulted in capturing 237 cities, towns, villages, and military bases from the Syrian regime. This marked a pivotal shift in the conflict, demonstrating the growing strength and coordination of opposition forces <citation>https://www.syriaweekly.com/p/special-syria-nov-26-dec-3-2024</citation>.

- **Strategic Advances Near Aleppo:** Opposition forces initiated a major offensive in western Aleppo, which resulted in the deaths of at least 89 individuals and the capture of a Syrian military base. Groups such as Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, associated with Al Qaeda, played a crucial role in advancing towards Aleppo, capturing weapons and military equipment from loyalist forces <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/27/world/middleeast/syria-opposition-forces-bases.html</citation>.

- **Geopolitical Implications:** The offensives presented a complex challenge for regional dynamics. While Russia and Iran faced new strategic dilemmas, Turkey found opportunities to solidify its influence in the region. These changes were indicative of a potential shift in power dynamics, leading to direct engagements and discussions among regional powers <citation>https://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2024-12-03/successful-offensive-syrian-opposition-forces-opportunity-turkey-and</citation>.

- **Rebel Strategy and Broader Consequences:** Beyond immediate military objectives, the offensives aimed to alter the status quo and compel regional powers like Turkey and Russia to negotiate under new ground realities. This move showcased the rebels' intent to challenge ongoing semi-ceasefire conditions and assert new strategic narratives <citation>https://gcclub.org/2024/12/02/syrias-rebel-offensive-why-now-and-what-could-happen-next/</citation>.
```

This content presents a comprehensive overview of the offensive strategies and their impact on the Syrian conflict in 2024.
